docs.lead_paragraph: In an odd bit of political jujitsu, Senate Republican leaders said today that they would use a Democratic bill as the main vehicle for four days of debate next week on the rights of patients buffeted by turmoil in the health care industry. The bill was introduced in January by the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, whose proposals are normally anathema to Republicans.

headline.main: In Ploy, G.O.P. Plans Debate on Democratic Patients' Bill

docs.abstract: Senate Republican leaders say they will use Democratic bill as main vehicle for four days of debate on rights of patients buffeted by turmoil in health care industry (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on June 19 about plans by Kaiser Permanente, the health maintenance organization, to discontinue operations in the Northeast referred incorrectly to the New Jersey unit of H.I.P. Health Plans of New York. State officials forced the unit to liquidate. It did not file for bankruptcy protection.
docs.abstract: Correction of June 19; state officials forced HIP Health Plans of New York's New Jersey unit to liquidate; it did not file for bankruptcy protection

docs.lead_paragraph: It may be the hot political issue of the moment in Washington, but from here, the Federal Government's rising debate over coverage of prescription drugs for the elderly looks a bit late, a bit leisurely. The Massachusetts Legislature, dominated by Democrats, has been grappling with the issue for months, and this week Gov. Paul Cellucci, a Republican, jumped in with his own plan for a state-run insurance program that would offer a form of drug coverage to all the state's elderly citizens.

headline.main: Massachusetts Chief Joins Effort on Drug Insurance for Elderly

docs.abstract: Massachusetts Gov Paul Cellucci, Republican, proposes state-run insurance program that would offer form of prescription drug coverage for all elderly; state's health maintenance organization have been slowly phasing out drug coverage since court overturned law requiring them to offer elderly option of full drug coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A July 2 front-page article reports that six million elderly Americans will face increased premiums and reduced benefits next year because of Medicare cuts and notes that this process ''undercuts a crucial part of President Clinton's Medicare proposal, which depends on competition among managed care plans.''

headline.main: Wanted: A National Commitment to Health Care

docs.abstract: Letter by Dr John C Baldwin, dean of Dartmouth Medical School, comments on July 2 article on Medicare cuts; says there should be a national commitment to create a right to health care

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans said today that they would seek to cut the top tax rate on long-term capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent as part of the big tax-cutting bill they will take up next week in the face of opposition from President Clinton. If enacted, the cut in the capital gains tax rate, which applies to profits on the sale of stock and other assets held for more than a year, would give a break to the growing legions of individual investors. And it could further fuel the long bull market on Wall Street, where stock prices hit another new high today. Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the capital gains tax cut would help keep the economy growing by stimulating additional savings and investment.

headline.main: G.O.P. to Seek Cut in Capital Gains Tax

docs.abstract: Rep Bill Archer, Ways and Means Committee head, says House Republicans will try to cut top tax rate on long-term capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent as part planned tax-cutting bill; outlook for cut is uncertain (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A July 4 Week in Review article faults anti-government sentiment for the Clinton Administration's failure in 1993 to pass legislation implementing universal health insurance. In fact, the public was manipulated and misinformed by negative sound bites designed to inflame this anti-government bias that were delivered by special interest groups seeking to defeat reform.

headline.main: Wanted: A National Commitment to Health Care

docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Philip Pollner, National Leadership Coalition for Health Care chairman, says special interest groups manipulated and misinformed the public about Clinton Administration's 1993 effort to establish universal health insurance (July 4 Week in Review article)
